metadata.name: n Forms #203
metadata.description:
Hand-scrawled documentation of abstract structures. A journal from another realm.

Press 's' to save an image while in full-screen mode.

If you want to increase the resolution of the saved image, add e.g. &size=2000 after the live/fullscreen view URL to render the canvas at that specific pixel width (default = browser sized). This will be dependent on your system specifications, but outputs of up to 8000px wide, or above, should be possible.

Usually loads best in Chrome

enjoy!

metadata.name: Dithered Nostalgia #28
metadata.description:
Have you ever struck by a sudden surge of nostalgia?
Making you stop everything you did at that moment,
Trying hard to remember the memory behind it, and failed to do so?

Each of these lands hold a nostalgia unlocked,
Like how good nostalgia are, it’s dithered and full of holes.
Holes that can be filled with your own memories and interpretations.

• • •

The second collaboration of MEK.txt and IceRain in FXHash. This time using MEK.txt’s landscape pixelart series and its distinctive dithering textures, brilliantly translated into code by IceRain to pixel-perfect iterations.

Dithered Nostalgia is a step up from MEK.txt & IceRain’s first project (Bento Boxes), trying to make more sophisticated, more detailed and challenging things based on something they passionate about; landscape.

Controls:
[1] Set the resolution to Medium Resolution
[2] Set the resolution to High Resolution

metadata.name: Tuesday #70
metadata.description: Maybe it's inspired by the marks left by coffee cups in my notebook. Maybe the doodles in that same notebook, often squares and circles, somehow influenced this work. Maybe the Bridget Riley book sitting on the shelf above gently whispered to me when I wasn't looking. Or maybe I just played with an idea and found it pleasing. The only thing I'm certain of – it was definitely a Tuesday.

metadata.name: Tangentum #159
metadata.description:
We live in a multiverse: an infinite-dimensional space of variants. Everything exists here. Everything is possible. Each subset of a multiverse has its own unique laws of physics, a set of rules, and its own distinct features.

Tangentum creates a projection of a random multiverse subset to a 2-dimensional plane. Each variation is a unique representation of the force field, that exists somewhere at some point in time.

This work starts a series of my visual exploration of functions, continuity, and boundedness, and I would love to share it with you.


Please use fullscreen or download artwork in high resolution for a better viewing experience.

Tested with Chrome 107, Safari, and Firefox. Chrome is recommended, other browsers are slower on this artwork.

Saving with high and ultra-high resolution may take a while, please be patient.


Made with love and p5js


Controls in fullscreen:
[1] - save PNG 2700 x 1800
[2] - save PNG 5400 x 3800
[3] - save PNG 10800 x 7600
[4] - save PNG 16200 x 11400

metadata.name: a fortiori #83
metadata.description:
Energy is everywhere: it’s moving our bodies, buzzing around a city, growing the universe, and connecting everything within it. Perhaps the strongest symbol humans use for energy – for ideas, life, and the various incarnations of power – is light itself. 

For centuries, each form of art has tried to capture the energetic luminescence of a bright light, a warm glow, a spark... if we could only draw with its pure brilliance! From Caravaggio’s diagonal beams, to Picasso drawing with light across Gjon Mili’s photographic emulsions… this pursuit persists through obsessive efforts by artists of every media. 

a fortiori seeks to capture this power of light with code, output on the native illumination of modern screens. The visual deconstruction of light and its reassembly into a frozen moment produces the tangible shards of each spark – resulting in a sum of marks that exceeds the value of their individual parts. It’s then the obsessive energy of generative art’s looping and controlled randomness that enable its repeated mark making, of all types, to express the nearly-intangible intensity of light.

What one hand might communicate in drawing, with light or stick or keyboard, 100 hands would therefore say 100 times louder, clearer, and more impactfully. And if one could capture the authentic energy of traveling light in a single image, it stands to reason that 500 of these images will multiply their energy-inducing qualities together, and exponentially grow their collective power. In this idea, the medium is the message – proving the power of the medium, and its ability to generate energy.


--------

TENDER x Thomas Noya
December 2022

Source code is licensed under the GNU Lesser General Public License as published by the Free Software Foundation.

a fortiori was created in p5.js and is optimized for live output in Chrome. Press these keys in live view to control the art and render high resolution versions of any token:

x = pause
y = play
1 = 1000x1000
2-9 = 2000x2000, …, 9000x9000
0 = 10000x10000
t = 12500x12500
f = 15000x15000
s = save PNG

Outputs beyond 10,000 pixels square are dependent on individual computer and browser capabilities. 

10% of all primary and secondary proceeds donated directly to Girls Who Code

◉_◉

metadata.name: Verdant Brut #23
metadata.description:
Verdant translates to “lush, green” and Brut means “dry, raw, or unrefined.”

This series is less about impressions of nature, or vegetal growth… but rather the vibrant, lush world that abstract art can provide and while certain iterations may serve Brutalist aesthetics, it tries to focus on the unrefined/raw aspect of the definition with more fluid shapes that feel irregular and organic in a playful, almost adolescent way.

Palettes inspired by MOMO, Melissa Wiederrecht, Erik Swahn, Marcelo Soria-Rodríguez, Paul Klee, Mareva Millarc, Ernst Mether-Borgström, Douglas Herbert Courtenay Auburn, Jim Harris, Alayne Spafford, Man Ray, Lajos Kassak and William Lachance. While the palettes may not always reflect their trademark colors (if they even have any) they are an homage to individual pieces by the respective artists that have influenced this series in their own way.

4878 bytes of Vanilla JS with no libraries.

For more info on the chosen palettes and other inspirations, see article linked from the main project page: Regarding Verdant Brut

In live mode:
‘S’ : save as png (2376 × 3360)
’V’ : save as svg (without grain)

URL params in live mode:
‘g=n’ : no grain
‘g=p’ : paper grain
‘h=t’ : high resolution mode, 5940 × 8400 (Chrome only)

For example, if you wanted paper grain in high resolution, append “&g=p&h=t” to the url in live mode.

After rendering with these params, tapping 'P' will then save the png with those settings applied.

metadata.name: Evolving World #5
metadata.description:
a wee experiment with p5js

It took me a long time to build this project, there were countless restarts until I finally found the path I wanted to follow.
As a multimedia artist I always like to learn new techniques, and when I discovered fxhash I had no doubts, I wanted to learn creative coding, and this is the result of my work and dedication.

I used mixed shapes with my greatest passion.
The color palettes were inspired by some painters I admire, making this work even more special and personal.
click anywhere on canvas to save the artwork.

metadata.name: MetaFlowers #4
metadata.description:
MetaFlowers was made using artificial intelligence
This NFT has a rarity

metadata.name: Mycenae #21
metadata.description:
The culmination of an extended project on Clifford attractors. These strange attractors are fractals, infinitely detailed but spacially bound. A generated token contains the generation parameters and so represents the infinite detail available.

It was an open question for me if these could be generated without curation. I think I succeeded in making it possible, balancing between variety and reliability. 

The project is named for my habit of naming art projects on Greek figures of myth. It seemed right to name the generation of such pieces on one of the Ancient Greek centres of civilisation.

metadata.name: Modulation #35
metadata.description:
Isometric cityscapes, patterns and geometries generated by trigonometric functions and rendered as SVG.

The SVG can be saved by pressing "s" on the full-screen view.
A PNG version can be exported by pressing "e" on the full-screen view.

By default the dimensions of the export are 6000×7500.
These dimensions can be changed by adding, for example, ?w=12000 to the full-screen page URL, where w is the desired width. Then press "e" to export at this size.

metadata.name: Splinter #42
metadata.description:
This release marks my first anniversary on the fx(hash) platform! I want to extend a huge thank you to everyone for a fantastic year, and I'm looking forward to many more in the generative-art world!

The basic algorithm is an evolution of the one I used in my first release, Raked Strokes. Instead of mimicking a brush with parallel segments, I'm using perpendicular line segments to define the overall abstract shape and then drawing each line in a simulated media. This approach blends my first attempts at natural media with everything I've learned in the past year.

Viewing in desktop Chrome is recommended for the best results.
Press 's' to save a screenshot. The image size is 2357x3000px
Press 'p' to pause/resume during drawing.

Features
- Base path shape: line, circle, diamond, or rectangle
- Elements defining the spacing and orientation of the line segments
- The base path painted in the background
- Monochrome, dark background, and selection of palettes
- Ink pen styling: thickness, quality, and background blocking
- Paint styling: color distribution, quality
- Shapes: triangle, polygons, criteria for insertion
- Shapes overdrawing: outlines or perpendicular segments

Copyright (c) 2022 Matt Perkins, hello@mattperkins.me, @nudoru on Twitter. Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, see LICENSE.txt for more information.
